title: Managing Intensity
description: Explore how you handle emotional intensity during conflict

questions.text: When conflict gets heated, we can usually bring the temperature down.

therapeutic.rationale: The ability to de-escalate is crucial. When couples can bring down intensity, conflicts don't spiral into damage. Without this skill, small issues become relationship wounds.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't experience successful de-escalation, explore what works and what doesn't. Humor? Breaks? Touch? Different approaches work for different couples.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ability to de-escalate protects your relationship during difficult moments.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps bring the temperature down when things get heated between you?

questions.text: I can stay calm enough to think clearly during disagreements.

therapeutic.rationale: When we're flooded with emotion, our thinking brain goes offline. Staying calm enough to think clearly allows you to respond rather than just react.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different levels of emotional regulation are normal. Partners can support each other by noticing flooding and taking breaks before damage is done.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to stay regulated creates thoughtful rather than reactive conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you stay calm during disagreements? What overwhelms you?

questions.text: We know when to take a break before things go too far.

therapeutic.rationale: Strategic breaks prevent escalation and regrettable words. Knowing when you're approaching the point of no return—and pausing—is a protective relationship skill.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't recognize when breaks are needed, discuss signals. Physical signs of flooding (racing heart, tension) indicate it's time to pause.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared awareness of when to pause protects you from saying things you'll regret.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you know when you need a break? Do you take them soon enough?

questions.text: After taking space, we come back to finish the conversation.

therapeutic.rationale: Breaks only work if couples return to the conversation. Taking space without returning can feel like abandonment or avoidance. The return matters as much as the pause.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't experience consistent return, explore what happens after breaks. Does the issue get dropped? Does one partner avoid? Committing to return builds trust.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared commitment to returning after breaks creates complete repair cycles.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens after you take space from a conflict? Do you come back to it?

questions.text: Our conflicts don't usually leave lasting emotional damage.

therapeutic.rationale: Healthy conflict resolves without permanent wounds. When conflicts leave lasting damage—hurt that doesn't heal, words that can't be forgotten—the relationship accumulates injuries.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner carries lasting damage from conflicts, explore what's causing the wounds. Specific words? Behaviors? Understanding the damage helps prevent future harm.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual experience of conflict without lasting damage indicates healthy patterns.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Have any of your conflicts left lasting hurt? What made those different?
